text:
For those of you wondering about how many seminars Chaincode runs in a year, I asked Adam Jonas, who said “3-4 [seminars] in a year. We run them once we have enough demand so more applicants mean we will run them more often.” 

If you’re interested in participating in a seminar, I encourage you to go apply here: https://chaincode.applytojob.com/apply/9I75v7voVu/Chaincode-Labs-Bitcoin-Protocol-Development-Seminar-Virtual

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Feel free to contact me if you need help with the application process.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Feel free to contact me if you need help with the application process. There is a mild technical portion to the application, but I don’t want that to prevent ppl from being considered, so lmk if you’re applying but don’t know how to code / are a beginner coder and I’ll help you with that portion.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Here’s a link for MVCC from last night, the internal database checkpointing system used by Oracle and PostgreSQL, etc.

To put things in perspective, UCB Prof & entrepreneur Michael Stonebraker was at the forefront of these developments. Postgres is so named because the first academic db research project called Ingress had already begun commercialization, so they were exceedingly creative in their next name. 🤷🏻‍♂️🙄🤣🤦🏻‍♂️

All this development and research was nearly contemporaneous with the development of TCP/IP and the BSD versions of Unix. Which begat the Unix Wars and which prompted the development of “Unix compatible” Linux.

No Unix Wars, no Linux. Try to imagine that 🤷🏻‍♂️

Heck, MicroSoft was an early leader in Unix systems via their Xenix platform. Oh well … Gates was smart enough to recognize Unix wouldn’t work as a mass market product and they got lucky as fuck with DEC laying off Dave Cutler and the VMS operating system team, which MSFT hired immediately for what we know today as NT. Boom 💥 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiversion_concurrency_control

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Lastly here’s a link for Paxos consensus algorithm.

Famously put into service by Google via their Big Table, Megastore & Spanner subsystems, which allowed for the creation of Gmail and their portfolio of consumer products.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Good morning ATL BitDevs! Just wanted to make a reminder that TAB Conf is coming up in September, and this year, all content (talks, workshops, builder day tables, etc) is OPEN SOURCE. What does that mean? It means TAB continues to lean into its community-led, grassroots style by letting the plebs build the schedule. If you want to talk about something at TAB, go to the github repo, and use one of the templates to submit content. The org team is actively vetting all submissions from now until Setpember, and as we get closer, they will be selecting the talks that get the most engagement on GH (i.e. emojis, comments, etc). https://twitter.com/tabconf/status/1666824544039108611

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
One NFC tag for the lightning wallet download. One NFC tag with a lightning LNURL-withdrawal URI that can then be interpreted by the Lightning wallet. Can use any NFC 215 Ntag. (https://docs.lnpay.co/api/lnurl-withdraw/how-does-lnurl-withdraw-work)

The LNURL-withdrawal tag is setup with a LNURL capable Lightning node/service. I used strike.army with my Strike account. Would withdrawal from my cash balance on Strike. (https://strike.army/)

It's a pretty seamless experience to get someone setup on Lightning.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Another angle to consider is this whole concept of gifting a paper wallet to somebody. Even supposing you generate the keys from a reliable source, once you've written them down, the person you are gifting it to doesn't have a reliable way of knowing who has and has not seen that piece of paper. Which might be fine for a smaller amount of bitcoin or a friend who trusts you, but it's not really the foundation for a scalable solution. But, it's easy. These things all have different trade-offs.

text: I have never had a chance to use a LISP meaningfully besides elisp hacking, some clojure dabbling, and some Guix experimentation, but I have a soft spot in my heart for the LISP family of languages. It’s awesome to meet someone with a background in it.  I also have a interest in building a cryptography background so I would love to chat more about your experience in the area! I am coming from a background in computer assisted proof development and proof automation and I will be entering a PhD program this August for the aim to build the skills required to become a cryptographer.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Joking aside, I helped found Anime Weekend Atlanta and Project A-Kon. Staffed Dragon*Con for over 20 years from registration to guest relations. Grew up in ComDex.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Anyone has any record keeping advice on how to maintain tax records and related documentation for capital gain reporting of BTC such that you minimize the amount of private information you have to provide to the government and third parties while maintaining tax compliance?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: For example, it seems that the only private record keeping solution is to maintain your own spreadsheet of transactions. I haven’t seen any capital gains calculation services for cryptocurrencies that didn’t involve a third party having access to the data. Has anyone run into an offline or trustless way to do it that is more convenient than manual spreadsheets?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: On the government end, I would prefer to use spec id over FIFO to minimize tax burden but I don’t want to give over public key and especially private key info. This leaves my only option to be keeping good records. However, the IRS does not give good info on what constitutes valid evidence of required information. Is it ok to use screenshots of transactions for apps that do not support CSV export?

text: I don't remember.  I do remember that Microsoft changed the interrupts my Junior year in college so MASM stopped working so I had to learn assembly on paper.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: /tip 1000 Thanks for sharing! Always insightful and informative!

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Interrupts are defined by Intel, the CPU.

0 - Timer, the heartbeat, the speed. Everything is dependent on this, ie the scheduler etc

1 - Single Step
3 - Breakpoint. CC hex, a single byte op code.

1 & 3 are how debuggers work.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
GUI?

I was incredibly fortunate to work in 1990 with Jef Raskin, the creator of the Macintosh UI/Project, at NCR on 10th Street GT’s ATDC after he got kicked outta Apple by Steven Jobs. Jef was designing the UI for an iPad device, NCR had a team or Smalltalkers prototyping the UI and was the missing link who wrote the assembler device drivers underneath the SmallTalk environment. Good times.

Microsoft caught wind of this and other projects and announced a famous Vaporware project called “Windows for Pen” and then NCR executives lost their nerve 🤷🏻‍♂️

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jef_Raskin

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: If your encryption is strong enough, there is no reason to obfuscate it. Once built a Twitter-based com system based on a sufficiently large dictionary (for compression not encryption) and a one-time pad. But hiding data in common images has been around for a few thousand years. Hiding it in the data of images has existed at least as long as lossy images have.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Steganography I think if the technical term

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Yeah, most steganography is contained within a single file tho. (At least that is how I have done it in the past) This example takes two hashed values from common looking files to derive a pubkey. Could distribute the files separately in two different secure communication channels and discretely share a pubkey.

I am not saying this is a good thing and is pretty silly. But for the purposes of a CTF challenge, it could be fun!😀

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Bryan, I previously DMed this to you but I figured I would share if here for anyone else who's interested:


-----

Here's a list of some companies offering "Linux-native" computers.  Of course, you can always install Linux on pretty much any computer, but when it ships with Linux, you can avoid issues with driver and hardware incompatibilities.  

Tuxedo (this is the brand I recently purchased): https://www.tuxedocomputers.com/en#

System76: https://system76.com

SlimBook: https://slimbook.es/en/store

Star Labs: https://us.starlabs.systems/pages/starfighter

HP has laptops that ship with Linux, plus they recently started developing a specific laptop aimed at developers: https://hpdevone.com/

Dell also offers some of its laptop shipping with Linux:  https://www.dell.com/en-us/shop/dell-laptops/xps-13-plus-developer-edition/spd/xps-13-9320-laptop/ctox13w11p1c4001u

And finally, Lenovo:  https://www.lenovo.com/us/en/p/laptops/thinkpad/thinkpadx1/thinkpad-x1-carbon-gen-10-(14-inch-intel)/21cbcto1wwus2

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
For those attending tomorrow's workshop, we will be learning how CoinJoin with Whirlpool, and how to set it up on our Bitcoin node.

Make sure to do the following beforehand so you'll be ready for the workshop:

1. Install a Whirlpool-compatible wallet:
 - Desktop: Sparrow
 - Android: Samourai
 - iOS: Bitcoin Keeper

2. Send some Bitcoin to that wallet. During the workshop you will learn how to CoinJoin that Bitcoin using Whirlpool.

3. If you have a personal node, make sure you can access it remotely through SSH.  Alternatively, bring your node to the workshop and we can help you set it up.

If you have any questions, feel free to DM me or @packetprotector

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
For those that use Umbrel, make sure to enable "Remote Tor Access" before coming and copy your auto-generated URL.

Once done, I can show you how to install Tailscale (VPN) on your node during the workshop so you can remotely SSH into your node.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: We're having similar discussions here in the workshop. I think @jordan_bravo is recommending that you don't mix the premix and postmix funds. Theoretically, you could be super careful and be sleective about which UTXOs you spend, but you're likely to mess something up on accident and mix them. So better to have them in separate wallets. IMHO, I think using the account feature in derivation path might be sufficient for that.

The 100,000 sat pool could take some time. I have left my funds in for over a month to get 5 mixes. If you set your mix threshold to 3 and specify a "Mix to" address, it will probably take 2-3 weeks for the 100,000 pool.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Can you pls show me next time how we use the account feature in the derivation path

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: It depends on the software. With Sparrow, I think the only way to do it is by changing the derivation path when importing the key. For example, if the derivation is m/84'/0'/0', then you would change it to m/84'/0'/1' to make a sub-account. If using Blockstream Green, I believe you can tap the cog to open up "Wallet Preferences" and then tap the "Create Account" button. I can demonstrate it sometime.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Not necessarily. The basic gist is this:
  
First, start a lightning node. We can host lightning nodes in the cloud for you at Voltage, or you could set it up yourself using your own cloud provider, or you could even set it up on your own physical device.
  
Next, you need inbound liquidity to start receiving payments. You can easily pay a small fee to have somebody open a channel to you, or a local pleb would probably open a channel to your node just to help you out.
  
That's all IF you want to run your own infrastructure. You could also just download something like Breez wallet and start accepting lightning payments with that. It even has a little built-in POS terminal.

Why people ask me about crypto IDK, but today I was asked: Should I do regular transactions with “Monero and fund it to liquidity out of butcoin”

I think they are asking if they should keep some amount of Monero (given the individual probably 3-5k USD equivalent) and then store things in Bitcoin (yes they typed butcoin) for long term storage and gain.

I said I have no clue but said I would ask around.

I assume this individual desires the privacy offered by Monero, as they have a record of shall we say… short term relationships which could result in legal garnishment.

text:
On Wednesday night, we're going to be looking at the leaked Google memo "We Have No Moat" that @ClockworkKat shared with us. This is an interesting piece because it really shows how powerful open source AI models are becoming. What does this have to do with bitcoin? Well, a hackathon kicked off this past weekend called AI 4 ALL. The goal of this hackathon is to integrate bitcoin/lightning with AI applications. As such, I thought this article would be a great discussion piece to get the creative juices flowing for participating in such an event. Have a great Independence Day, and we'll see you on Wednesday. 🇺🇸
https://www.meetup.com/atlantabitdevs/events/294526783/

specifically, line 83 is the input layer followed by multiple hidden layers each with 200 input nodes (the blue circles last night).

text: I built a telegram bot that uses chat GPT. Its storing messages from the ATL BitDevs telegram group, and then by running the summary command, it will look back 1 week and for each day, summarize the messages of that day, so we can more easily and quickly create the weekly newsletter.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Just to clarify, I was making implicit reference to free markets being a tool to adjust resources by aggregating collective knowledge. Earlier in the talk there was a passing reference to this in the talk in the context of disliking central planning being it was less efficient at doing this than a free market. Hearing this made me consider that perhaps Austrian theorists had an answer to information silos because on the surface an information silo would impact a market’s ability to adjust value to resources. Because closed source software seemed similar to an information silo, I was curious about information silos in the Austrian context.

If you have an android and are interested in being a guinea pig to help me find bugs, please let me know and either DM me a gmail address or send one here and i'll add you.

!! Be aware: the app backend is live and using a production version of Plaid, so registratin will require real PII (name, address, DOB, phonenumber, etc.). If you're not comfortable signing up with real information, no worries. Wanted to make sure you all were aware of that.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Synthetic USD? Powered by DLCs?

If anyone knows what that means, would probably be a good presentation topic.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
It's one of those topics I typically start rambling sometime after the 2nd beer. Basically, you use a price oracle and a discrete log contract to create something that resembles a dollar if you squint at it.
  
Alice wants the stability of the dollar andBob wants to try and earn some yield on his BTC. Alice and Bob enter into a DLC together. Alice contributes $1 worth of bitcoin, Bob contributes $2 worth of bitcoin. Alice can redeem this UTXO for $1 worth of bitcoin and Bob gets the leftovers. If the price goes up, then Bob has profited. If the price goes down, he has lost a little, but Alice still has her $1.
  
There are edge cases to worry about like what if the price dips too much, what if the oracle goes down, what's the best way to do this on lightning, etc. And there are ways of mitigating and responding to these situations. But that's the basic gist of it.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
I’ve got a little bit of a theoretical question and was curious if anyone might have an opinion on this.

If bitcoin were the only currency of the world, would it be relatively fair to say that owning 21 bitcoin would equate to owning an IOU for about one millionth of the world’s resources? In other words, would all of the world’s resources/ “the value of the world economy” add up to roughly 21 million bitcoin? I understand value is subjective and assets would still fluctuate in price over/under-evaluation so I know it wouldn’t be perfectly 21 million but am curious if this is still a “relatively” fair thing to say to explain bitcoin to normies? (And for semantics, let’s assume that all 21 million bitcoin have been mined and can be used (i.e. none have been “lost”)).

(I ask bc I’m writing and article on inflation/money and wanted to add some tidbits ab bitcoin.) I appreciate any help!

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: That's an interesting thought experiment. I don't know if I'd call it an "IOU", but it does seem correct to say that if it's the only currency used, you then own one millionth of the world's *purchasing power*. I don't think it's accurate to say that it's worth one millionth of world resources. For example, imagine jewelry composed of gold and precious stones that has been passed down through the family for generations. It might fetch a fair amount of bitcoin on the open market, but if it's precious family heirloom, then its not for sale. I'm sure one could think of other examples of resource that. effectively aren;t for sale. So IMHO, more accurate to think in terms of purchasing power rather than actual claims to resources.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: That's an interesting thought experiment. I don't know if I'd call it an "IOU", but it does seem correct to say that if it's the only currency used, you then own one millionth of the world's *purchasing power*. I don't think it's accurate to say that it's worth one millionth of world resources. For example, imagine jewelry composed of gold and precious stones that has been passed down through the family for generations. It might fetch a fair amount of bitcoin on the open market, but if it's precious family heirloom, then its not for sale. I'm sure one could think of other examples of resource that effectively aren't for sale. So IMHO, more accurate to think in terms of purchasing power rather than actual claims to resources.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
True. Purchasing power may be a better phrasing. And yeah, I agree, when you get to nitty gritty of subjective value bc, in theory, there are some things that people wouldn’t sell for all of the money in the world.

I’m just trying to think of a more concrete way of explaining the idea to people. Bc saying “you own one millionth of the world’s purchasing power” still is an abstract idea and not as concrete. Like it’s hard for people who know literally nothing about money to understand what that means. Any thoughts on a more concrete way to explain it? I can still work it in if not, but just getting something more tangible/concrete that people understand would help.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Without knowing exactly what you’re trying to accomplish in the span of one artificle, it’s probably best to go for the very fundamental basics of money first.

E.g. why money/what is money/what should money be
IMHO the best first point to make is money should represent time/energy. You can’t take the energy in your body right now with you ten years into the future, nor the present moment, so you trade those for something you can. That lends itself to introducing salability across time & salability across space as definitions, then Coincidence of wants, then path dependence from SoV to MoE to UoA… then there’s a framework in place to assess Bitcoin against other monetized assets. Lots of good resources cover this as a reference; I believe Vijay Boyapati covered a lot of those fundamentals succinctly in both the article & book version of The Bullish Case for Bitcoin

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion

True. Purchasing power may be a better phrasing. And yeah, I agree, when you get to nitty gritty of subjective value bc, in theory, there are some things that people wouldn’t sell for all of the money in the world.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
I agree with the the time / energy argument - with the additional note that bitcoin has the advantage of diminishing supply over time with an ultimately fixed final supply known in advance. 

Following the famous economic maxim ' compared to what" most human good increase their supply and degrade over time- so it's no simply 21 / vs today's global supply- it is 21 vs the supply 100 years from now.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
It's one of those topics I typically start rambling sometime after the 2nd beer. Basically, you use a price oracle and a discrete log contract to create something that resembles a dollar if you squint at it.
  
Alice wants the stability of the dollar andBob wants to try and earn some yield on his BTC. Alice and Bob enter into a DLC together. Alice contributes $1 worth of bitcoin, Bob contributes $2 worth of bitcoin. Alice can redeem this UTXO for $1 worth of bitcoin and Bob gets the leftovers. If the price goes up, then Bob has profited. If the price goes down, he has lost a little, but Alice still has her $1.
  
There are edge cases to worry about like what if the price dips too much, what if the oracle goes down, what's the best way to do this on lightning, etc. And there are ways of mitigating and responding to these situations. But that's the basic gist of it.

text: if the fee rate decimal value, how do you calculate 500 mSAT per 1000000 SATs moved?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: LL docs says the fee_rate is a decimal value, and the fee_per_mill is in mSATs. how do you calculate the 500 mSAT using the 0.000001 fee_rate?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
best i got is to divide by 2 and multiple by 1000000 but idk why you would divide by 2
0.000001 / 2 = 0.0000005 * 1,000,000 = 0.5 SATs 
and that still doesnt get the mSAT value, which requires 0.5 * 1000 = 500 mSATs
is there a formula for using the fee_rate (ppm) to directly calcuate the mSATs per HTLC routed?

If you have any questions, please feel free to ask in here or DM myself or @packetprotector

Edit to add:  in the interest of time, beforehand you should already have a Bitcoin full node up and running with synced blockchain data, and an indexer such as Electrum server or Fulcrum.

Again, if you have any questions on setting this up, please don't hesitate to ask.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: @jordan_bravo and @Tapatingo , could you share your experiences and why you feel this service is valuable? I’m a bit skeptical of the value proposition in light of telegram and nostr. It doesn’t seem worth the privacy compromises with respect to geolocation especially given that there are ways for malicious users to fake their geolocation so not allowing users to put in a country and zip code combo isn’t protecting users from malicious users.  On the other hand, similar compromises are made using Meetup and I wouldn’t know about this wonderful group without Meetup. From this perspective, Orange Pill seems like a more focused version of Meetup.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Here’s a link for MVCC from last night, the internal database checkpointing system used by Oracle and PostgreSQL, etc.

To put things in perspective, UCB Prof & entrepreneur Michael Stonebraker was at the forefront of these developments. Postgres is so named because the first academic db research project called Ingress had already begun commercialization, so they were exceedingly creative in their next name. 🤷🏻‍♂️🙄🤣🤦🏻‍♂️

All this development and research was nearly contemporaneous with the development of TCP/IP and the BSD versions of Unix. Which begat the Unix Wars and which prompted the development of “Unix compatible” Linux.

No Unix Wars, no Linux. Try to imagine that 🤷🏻‍♂️

Heck, MicroSoft was an early leader in Unix systems via their Xenix platform. Oh well … Gates was smart enough to recognize Unix wouldn’t work as a mass market product and they got lucky as fuck with DEC laying off Dave Cutler and the VMS operating system team, which MSFT hired immediately for what we know today as NT. Boom 💥 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiversion_concurrency_control

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Lastly here’s a link for Paxos consensus algorithm.

Famously put into service by Google via their Big Table, Megastore & Spanner subsystems, which allowed for the creation of Gmail and their portfolio of consumer products.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Good morning ATL BitDevs! Just wanted to make a reminder that TAB Conf is coming up in September, and this year, all content (talks, workshops, builder day tables, etc) is OPEN SOURCE. What does that mean? It means TAB continues to lean into its community-led, grassroots style by letting the plebs build the schedule. If you want to talk about something at TAB, go to the github repo, and use one of the templates to submit content. The org team is actively vetting all submissions from now until Setpember, and as we get closer, they will be selecting the talks that get the most engagement on GH (i.e. emojis, comments, etc). https://twitter.com/tabconf/status/1666824544039108611

That's why in order to do it right you have to download the source and generate on an airgapped device.  Before HD keys, this was pretty much the only way to do analog cold storage.

If done properly they are extremely trustworthy, if a bit outmoded.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
There was also one generator that was bought out by scammers and turned into a honeypot, this has given paper wallets a bad rep.

In the early days you had problems with lost funds because people didn't understand how change addresses work and wallets weren't mature.

text:
One NFC tag for the lightning wallet download. One NFC tag with a lightning LNURL-withdrawal URI that can then be interpreted by the Lightning wallet. Can use any NFC 215 Ntag. (https://docs.lnpay.co/api/lnurl-withdraw/how-does-lnurl-withdraw-work)

The LNURL-withdrawal tag is setup with a LNURL capable Lightning node/service. I used strike.army with my Strike account. Would withdrawal from my cash balance on Strike. (https://strike.army/)

It's a pretty seamless experience to get someone setup on Lightning.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Another angle to consider is this whole concept of gifting a paper wallet to somebody. Even supposing you generate the keys from a reliable source, once you've written them down, the person you are gifting it to doesn't have a reliable way of knowing who has and has not seen that piece of paper. Which might be fine for a smaller amount of bitcoin or a friend who trusts you, but it's not really the foundation for a scalable solution. But, it's easy. These things all have different trade-offs.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: For example, it seems that the only private record keeping solution is to maintain your own spreadsheet of transactions. I haven’t seen any capital gains calculation services for cryptocurrencies that didn’t involve a third party having access to the data. title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: On the government end, I would prefer to use spec id over FIFO to minimize tax burden but I don’t want to give over public key and especially private key info. Is it ok to use screenshots of transactions for apps that do not support CSV export?

Name Interrupts 0, 1 & 3

text: I don't remember.  I do remember that Microsoft changed the interrupts my Junior year in college so MASM stopped working so I had to learn assembly on paper.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: /tip 1000 Thanks for sharing! Always insightful and informative!

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Interrupts are defined by Intel, the CPU.

0 - Timer, the heartbeat, the speed. Everything is dependent on this, ie the scheduler etc

1 - Single Step
3 - Breakpoint. CC hex, a single byte op code.

1 & 3 are how debuggers work.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
GUI?

I was incredibly fortunate to work in 1990 with Jef Raskin, the creator of the Macintosh UI/Project, at NCR on 10th Street GT’s ATDC after he got kicked outta Apple by Steven Jobs. Jef was designing the UI for an iPad device, NCR had a team or Smalltalkers prototyping the UI and was the missing link who wrote the assembler device drivers underneath the SmallTalk environment. Good times.

Microsoft caught wind of this and other projects and announced a famous Vaporware project called “Windows for Pen” and then NCR executives lost their nerve 🤷🏻‍♂️

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jef_Raskin

Bryan, I previously DMed this to you but I figured I would share if here for anyone else who's interested:


-----

Here's a list of some companies offering "Linux-native" computers.  Of course, you can always install Linux on pretty much any computer, but when it ships with Linux, you can avoid issues with driver and hardware incompatibilities.  

Tuxedo (this is the brand I recently purchased): https://www.tuxedocomputers.com/en#

System76: https://system76.com

SlimBook: https://slimbook.es/en/store

Star Labs: https://us.starlabs.systems/pages/starfighter

HP has laptops that ship with Linux, plus they recently started developing a specific laptop aimed at developers: https://hpdevone.com/

Dell also offers some of its laptop shipping with Linux:  https://www.dell.com/en-us/shop/dell-laptops/xps-13-plus-developer-edition/spd/xps-13-9320-laptop/ctox13w11p1c4001u

And finally, Lenovo:  https://www.lenovo.com/us/en/p/laptops/thinkpad/thinkpadx1/thinkpad-x1-carbon-gen-10-(14-inch-intel)/21cbcto1wwus2

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
For those attending tomorrow's workshop, we will be learning how CoinJoin with Whirlpool, and how to set it up on our Bitcoin node.

Make sure to do the following beforehand so you'll be ready for the workshop:

1. Install a Whirlpool-compatible wallet:
 - Desktop: Sparrow
 - Android: Samourai
 - iOS: Bitcoin Keeper

2. Send some Bitcoin to that wallet. During the workshop you will learn how to CoinJoin that Bitcoin using Whirlpool.

3. If you have a personal node, make sure you can access it remotely through SSH.  Alternatively, bring your node to the workshop and we can help you set it up.

If you have any questions, feel free to DM me or @packetprotector

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
For those that use Umbrel, make sure to enable "Remote Tor Access" before coming and copy your auto-generated URL.

Once done, I can show you how to install Tailscale (VPN) on your node during the workshop so you can remotely SSH into your node.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: It depends on the software. With Sparrow, I think the only way to do it is by changing the derivation path when importing the key. For example, if the derivation is m/84'/0'/0', then you would change it to m/84'/0'/1' to make a sub-account. If using Blockstream Green, I believe you can tap the cog to open up "Wallet Preferences" and then tap the "Create Account" button. I can demonstrate it sometime.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Not necessarily. The basic gist is this:
  
First, start a lightning node. We can host lightning nodes in the cloud for you at Voltage, or you could set it up yourself using your own cloud provider, or you could even set it up on your own physical device.
  
Next, you need inbound liquidity to start receiving payments. You can easily pay a small fee to have somebody open a channel to you, or a local pleb would probably open a channel to your node just to help you out.
  
That's all IF you want to run your own infrastructure. You could also just download something like Breez wallet and start accepting lightning payments with that. It even has a little built-in POS terminal.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: It depends on the software. With Sparrow, I think the only way to do it is by changing the derivation path when importing the key. For example, if the derivation is m/84'/0'/0', then you would change it to m/84'/0'/1' to make a sub-account. If using Blockstream Green, I believe you can tap the cog to open up "Wallet Preferences" and then tap the "Create Account" button. I can demonstrate it sometime.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
strike.me is the official Strike provided LN address, strike.army is a solution made by one of our former devs. 

strike.army was built a year ago and was how people could get LNURL functionality with their Strike account.

As of last month, Strike has started supporting LN addresses natively.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Why people ask me about crypto IDK, but today I was asked: Should I do regular transactions with “Monero and fund it to liquidity out of butcoin”

I think they are asking if they should keep some amount of Monero (given the individual probably 3-5k USD equivalent) and then store things in Bitcoin (yes they typed butcoin) for long term storage and gain.

I said I have no clue but said I would ask around.

I assume this individual desires the privacy offered by Monero, as they have a record of shall we say… short term relationships which could result in legal garnishment.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: They could use lightning. Why monero.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Because thats what they asked? Again I assume its due to anonymity and a presumption that they can run a set of parallel funds, but I learned a ling time ago that some people you simply do not ask. (I was an IT forensics tech and analyst in the early 2000’s for a PI, thats where I know this individual from their parent was one of our clients 20 years ago)

text:
On Wednesday night, we're going to be looking at the leaked Google memo "We Have No Moat" that @ClockworkKat shared with us. This is an interesting piece because it really shows how powerful open source AI models are becoming. What does this have to do with bitcoin? Well, a hackathon kicked off this past weekend called AI 4 ALL. The goal of this hackathon is to integrate bitcoin/lightning with AI applications. As such, I thought this article would be a great discussion piece to get the creative juices flowing for participating in such an event. Have a great Independence Day, and we'll see you on Wednesday. 🇺🇸
https://www.meetup.com/atlantabitdevs/events/294526783/

Great idea! My friend Christoph created Nosta.Me which is sort of like an onboarding tool for Nostr. I think he wanted to start adding some "What Next" type of content eventually, like recommending services that people can start using their Nostr profile with. Might be room for potential collaboration here.
  
In terms of relays, Nostream and StirFry would be examples. However, these are more developer focused things, and I don't think end users need to be too concerned with which particular software a relay is running, IMHO.

text: That’s a silly question. Information silos are a free market.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: That’s a silly question. Information silos reflect/are a free market.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Just to clarify, I was making implicit reference to free markets being a tool to adjust resources by aggregating collective knowledge. Earlier in the talk there was a passing reference to this in the talk in the context of disliking central planning being it was less efficient at doing this than a free market. Hearing this made me consider that perhaps Austrian theorists had an answer to information silos because on the surface an information silo would impact a market’s ability to adjust value to resources. Because closed source software seemed similar to an information silo, I was curious about information silos in the Austrian context.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: This book was mentioned in the Genesis book lol

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: I suspect that siloed information inevitably disperses to the whole market and cannot be forever trapped by a few. If true, then you do not need a model to enforce free code like the GPL; closed information derived from a permissive license will eventually become open

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Good morning BitLabers! Some exciting news for me this week. I’ve officially launched the Liberty Pay alpha test to the Google Play store. If you have an android and are interested in being a guinea pig to help me find bugs, please let me know and either DM me a gmail address or send one here and i'll add you.

!! Be aware: the app backend is live and using a production version of Plaid, so registratin will require real PII (name, address, DOB, phonenumber, etc.). Upon registration, you will have a LP account created with your PII stored in our DB, and then you'll be put through a production Plaid Identity verification flow which stores that PII from the registration form in the Plaid production backend as well. If you're not comfortable signing up with real information, no worries. Wanted to make sure you all were aware of that.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Synthetic USD? Powered by DLCs?

If anyone knows what that means, would probably be a good presentation topic.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
It's one of those topics I typically start rambling sometime after the 2nd beer. Basically, you use a price oracle and a discrete log contract to create something that resembles a dollar if you squint at it.
  
Alice wants the stability of the dollar andBob wants to try and earn some yield on his BTC. Alice and Bob enter into a DLC together. Alice contributes $1 worth of bitcoin, Bob contributes $2 worth of bitcoin. Alice can redeem this UTXO for $1 worth of bitcoin and Bob gets the leftovers. If the price goes up, then Bob has profited. If the price goes down, he has lost a little, but Alice still has her $1.
  
There are edge cases to worry about like what if the price dips too much, what if the oracle goes down, what's the best way to do this on lightning, etc. And there are ways of mitigating and responding to these situations. But that's the basic gist of it.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
I’ve got a little bit of a theoretical question and was curious if anyone might have an opinion on this.

If bitcoin were the only currency of the world, would it be relatively fair to say that owning 21 bitcoin would equate to owning an IOU for about one millionth of the world’s resources? In other words, would all of the world’s resources/ “the value of the world economy” add up to roughly 21 million bitcoin? I understand value is subjective and assets would still fluctuate in price over/under-evaluation so I know it wouldn’t be perfectly 21 million but am curious if this is still a “relatively” fair thing to say to explain bitcoin to normies? (And for semantics, let’s assume that all 21 million bitcoin have been mined and can be used (i.e. none have been “lost”)).

(I ask bc I’m writing and article on inflation/money and wanted to add some tidbits ab bitcoin.) I appreciate any help!

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: That's an interesting thought experiment. I don't know if I'd call it an "IOU", but it does seem correct to say that if it's the only currency used, you then own one millionth of the world's *purchasing power*. I don't think it's accurate to say that it's worth one millionth of world resources. For example, imagine jewelry composed of gold and precious stones that has been passed down through the family for generations. It might fetch a fair amount of bitcoin on the open market, but if it's precious family heirloom, then its not for sale. I'm sure one could think of other examples of resource that. effectively aren;t for sale. So IMHO, more accurate to think in terms of purchasing power rather than actual claims to resources.

I can still work it in if not, but just getting something more tangible/concrete that people understand would help.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Without knowing exactly what you’re trying to accomplish in the span of one artificle, it’s probably best to go for the very fundamental basics of money first.

E.g. why money/what is money/what should money be
IMHO the best first point to make is money should represent time/energy. You can’t take the energy in your body right now with you ten years into the future, nor the present moment, so you trade those for something you can. That lends itself to introducing salability across time & salability across space as definitions, then Coincidence of wants, then path dependence from SoV to MoE to UoA… then there’s a framework in place to assess Bitcoin against other monetized assets. Lots of good resources cover this as a reference; I believe Vijay Boyapati covered a lot of those fundamentals succinctly in both the article & book version of The Bullish Case for Bitcoin

text:
I agree with the the time / energy argument - with the additional note that bitcoin has the advantage of diminishing supply over time with an ultimately fixed final supply known in advance. 

Following the famous economic maxim ' compared to what" most human good increase their supply and degrade over time- so it's no simply 21 / vs today's global supply- it is 21 vs the supply 100 years from now.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
It's one of those topics I typically start rambling sometime after the 2nd beer. Basically, you use a price oracle and a discrete log contract to create something that resembles a dollar if you squint at it.
  
Alice wants the stability of the dollar andBob wants to try and earn some yield on his BTC. Alice and Bob enter into a DLC together. Alice contributes $1 worth of bitcoin, Bob contributes $2 worth of bitcoin. Alice can redeem this UTXO for $1 worth of bitcoin and Bob gets the leftovers. If the price goes up, then Bob has profited. If the price goes down, he has lost a little, but Alice still has her $1.
  
There are edge cases to worry about like what if the price dips too much, what if the oracle goes down, what's the best way to do this on lightning, etc. And there are ways of mitigating and responding to these situations. But that's the basic gist of it.

title: atlantabitdevs
text:
🇸🇻💥💰🤑 — El Salvador President Nayib Bukele scared off many on Wall Street by embracing Bitcoin. Two years later, the bond rally he’s overseeing is proving too lucrative to resist.

Eye-popping 70% returns — the best among dollar bonds from emerging markets this year — are attracting investors who were once cautious or avoiding the securities altogether. JPMorgan Chase & Co, Eaton Vance and PGIM Fixed Income are among those who have recommended or bought the debt, betting it will continue climbing.

“Although we missed a significant share of the rally, we still think there’s value across El Salvador’s curve,” JPMorgan research strategists Ben Ramsey, Nishant Poojary and Gorka Lalaguna wrote in a July note, moving overweight on the debt. “There’s room for this credit to keep outperforming.”

The optimism demonstrates how Bukele has gained acceptance from both money managers and his peers in Latin America after many had dismissed him as an anti-establishment maverick. His hard-line stance on gangs, which has dramatically cut crime in the country, is influencing politics throughout the region. And his commitment to paying bondholders is making him a favorite among emerging-market investors.

Source 🔗

title: atlantabitdevs
text: I was actually just chatting with David Harding the other day about the 3rd edition. (He's the author of the 3rd edition). The 3rd edition of Mastering Bitcoin will be released in print later this year. The open source version will go on GitHub after that.
name: sbddesign

title: atlantabitdevs
text:
I'd personally like to wait until the 3rd edition is out before conducting a reading group series on the book, as it will cover taproot, schnorr, and feature segwit as a first-class citizen and not some interesting new concept.
  
Having said that @YourCryptoDoctor, the 2nd edition is still great and if you're itching to explore the technical, I say you should go for it and dive in 🤙

text:
In the bustling city of Atlanta, the esteemed members of the BitPlebs Society shall reconvene at the venerable Manuel's Tavern on the twenty-third day of August. They shall indulge in sumptuous fare, refreshing libations, and engage in spirited discourse upon the topic of Bitcoin.

It is foreseen that our conversation shall be punctuated with recent happenings and primarily directed towards the much-anticipated Halving of the Bitcoin in the early days of 2024. One might say, the populace remains quite unprepared for the forthcoming events!

While the majority amongst us harbour intentions of procuring their own sustenance and spirits from dear Manuel's, those who venture to make an early appearance shall be graced with complimentary beverages.
  
https://www.meetup.com/atlanta-bitplebs/events/295475406/
name: sbddesign

title: atlantabitdevs
text:
Hey all! Rich from Blockstream here. 

Wanted to reach out as our team is always eager to learn more about our audience’s needs, expectations, and pain points regarding their wallet use (both software+hardware) so we can continue building compelling solutions for Bitcoiners.

If you are:

- Happy with how you’re securing your Bitcion
- Unhappy or have concerns with your current self-custody solution
- Uncertain about wallets and which to choose
- Or if you just want to rant about any wallet related topic… 

Our team would love to speak with you. If you’re interested in providing your insight, please send me a DM.

Thanks in advance!
name: richg90

title: atlantabitdevs
text:
Hey all! Rich from Blockstream here. 

Wanted to reach out as our team is always eager to learn more about our audience’s needs, expectations, and pain points regarding their wallet use (both software+hardware) so we can continue building compelling solutions for Bitcoiners.

If you are:

- Happy with how you’re securing your Bitcoin
- Unhappy or have concerns with your current self-custody solution
- Uncertain about wallets and which to choose
- Or if you just want to rant about any wallet related topic… 

Our team would love to speak with you. If you’re interested in providing your insight, please send me a DM.

Thanks in advance!

name: YourCryptoDoctor

title: Atlanta BitDevs Discussion
text: Was scrolling through this chat and saw this. Borrowing against your bitcoin can also be an option. That’s basically the problem the Lava Loans Protocol is solving, helping you borrow against bitcoin safely and easily in self-custody. If you’re LT bullish on bitcoin and think BTC appreciation will be higher than the interest rate you can get on a BTC backed loan, borrowing makes sense. But when you’re borrowing, you want to make sure your BTC collateral won’t get rehypothecated, lost, or confiscated in a loan. using Lava, you can lock BTC in a programmed contract and receive stablecoins (which you can convert to fiat for basically free if you want). The protocol makes loan terms transparent to you, gives you confidence the collateral won’t be lost stolen or confiscated, and doesn’t require you to KYC, sign a bunch of paperwork, and wait many days. There are some risks like using a set of oracles. Lava tries to minimize the risks as much as possible through creating optionality, redundancy, and privacy (you can choose your own oracle, you can choose a large set of oracles, you can make sure oracles don’t even know you’re using their price feeds in a contract, etc). I can speak more to this if you’re interested.

title: burner:tabweekparty
text:
Frostsnap
- most self-custody is the same: single HW wallet, pin, physical copy of mneumonic
- multisig is still too difficult for most users
 - what are some of these challenges of multisig?
 - how can we make it easier?
- frostsnap uses FROST to create an easier-to-use, easier-to-update multisignature wallet
 - FROST (Flexible Round-Optimized Schnorr Threshold Signatures)
 - Allows for key aggregation: multiple pubkeys can be combined to create a new pubkey that is an aggregate of all 3
 - Allows for a single key to be on-chain, but still requires n-of-m signatures
 - Signatures can also be aggregated into 1 signature that can be verified against the single aggregated pubkey
- Uses m devices to create a FROST-multisig wallet
- If a device is lost of stolen, that device's key can be make incompatible and replaced with a new key without an on-chain tx
 - How does this work?
 - My understanding:
  - Replacing a private key => a new public key
  - Replacing public key => new aggregated pubkey? => different signature than prior to change?
  - New aggregated pubkey => new wallet address for funds? => Need to move funds from old aggPK to new aggPK?
- Current multisig requires an on-chain movement of funds to swap in/out a key because ECDSA does not support linear key aggregation
- Bc schnorr taproot => more private
- Bc schnorr taproot => less on-chain data => lower tx fees
- Extensible to be used for things like nostr
- FROST key creation happens off chain, so how does the aggPK commit to UTXOs?
-

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Hey, I'd love to onboard people from here to Lava this week. 

Lava enables a best-in-class UX for self-custody while offering:
1. a flexible and robust safety and recovery solution
2. global support for buy/sell
3. receive and send bitcoin/dollars in self-custody. moving dollars using lava is global, instant, and free
4. borrow against your bitcoin *being enabled soon

I'd love to get feedback from the people here who really know and care about self-custody. If you're interested and aren't already using Lava, can you please add your email to our waitlist on our website, and I'll send you the invite today: lava.xyz

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: What is the lava smart key?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
I'll send more details in the email I send to onboard you, but Lava Smart Key is our security solution. We think about security as 2 things: protecting users from malicious parties accessing their funds (safety) and enabling users to always be able to recover their funds (recovery). Lava Smart Key is designed to be a flexible and robust security solution, one that users can personalize and upgrade over time. 

The most important part right now is our recovery solution. Most wallets use seedphrases, or if they offer seedless backups, most wallets will encrypt via the 4 digit PIN or the 8 digit password they ask you to enter. This is a bad solution for 2 reasons: a malicious attacker who compromises the encrypted information (usually stored on a user's cloud) can trivially break the encryption and access the seed but a novice user (if they forget their PIN/password won't be able to access their funds. 

We wanted to build a system where backups where bullet proof and couldn't be brute-forced but also a system that users could trust to confidently recover their wallet if need be. 

So, Lava's solution employs the use of a key-server, where a 4 digit PIN is mapped to a high entropy encryption key. That encryption key is used to encrypt the seed. The encrypted material is stored in your cloud in secure storage. Rate limits are enforced on keyserver to prevent brute force attacks, and if you think you’ll forget your PIN you can even set a PIN recovery method to recover it after a 30 day time delay. 

The key here is that there’s no single point of failure. Lava Smart Key is creating a 2 of 2 backup, and it's giving you flexibility to set how you want to recover each side of the backup.

If you're worried if you’ll forget your PIN? You can set a PIN recovery method.
or worried you’ll lose access to your cloud? You can set  a social recovery contact(s).

Our recovery solution sets a strong foundation that can serve a user just starting their self-custody journey to an OG who is increasing their stack of sats. and for the OG, they can upgrade security over time with new upgrades we'll make to Lava Smart Key that'll provide greater protection from for example malware risks or  wrench attacks.

In the onboarding email, I'll send you a blog I wrote that goes way more in depth about Lava Smart Key as well as a Transparency Document highlighting all the risks you take when using Lava.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: How is this not a back door? Like the Liberty Safe situation?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
The keyserver doesn't store any personally identifying information, including your number/email (if you choose to even add that as a recovery method for your 4 digit PIN (if you forget your PIN, you can change it after 30 day time delay authenticated via PIN recovery method)). The encryption key is stored on the key-servers (resistant from brute force attacks), but even if someone compromised all the encryption keys, they'd need to compromise encrypted material stored in iCloud/GDrive secure storage. and they'd have to do this before users were aware of the compromise and took necessary steps to protect themselves.

And we've built ways for you to mitigate the risks with Lava Smart Key if you want. 

If you're worried we will somehow censor all of our users from recovering their wallet (by turning of keyserver), then you can create fully sovereign paper backups. 
If you're worried Apple and Lava will collude against all of our users, and in that time no one else would know about it, you can opt out of the 2 of 2 cloud backup solution and create only paper backups. 


In that blog, I describe other risks/mitigations. What we think is necessary is a foundation is that is secure and serves the 99 percent of users well. for the other 1 percent, give them flexibility to mitigate other possible risks if they care to do so.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
btw, this exact part of Lava Smart Key that we're discussing is our implementation of Photon: https://docs.photonsdk.org/

Photon is an open-source project funded by Spiral. Steve Lee brought it up to me as Lava was experimenting with all the various possibilities for a recovery solution.

I hope the above 2 messages help explain the tech better. I want to improve our messaging and make it very clear to users the benefits, downsides, and what people can do to personalize security.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
I don’t think there’s one summary of the ArsDigita/Philip Greenspun story but expert google Fu should find something.

Philip played an outsized role in early Web Development, starting with Photo.net in 1993. Ars was instrumental in pioneering early sophisticated Open Source backend software stack. They convinced AOL to release AOLServer and they discovered Postgres95, which is now PostgreSQL. They also published OpenACS and early Django like framework.

Anyway, so many (white) rabbits to follow.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
I don’t think there’s one summary of the ArsDigita/Philip Greenspun story but expert google Fu should find something.

Philip played an outsized role in early Web Development, starting with Photo.net in 1993. Ars was instrumental in pioneering early sophisticated Open Source backend software stack. They convinced AOL to release AOLServer and they discovered Postgres95, which is now PostgreSQL. They also published OpenACS an early Django like framework.

So what’s really important/neat about the final flameout of ArsDigita, is the cautionary tale of accepting VC money. In the late 90’s VC’s were so hungry for deals, etc Philip finally succumbed. Long story short, VCs destroyed Ars, Philip sued the VC, Greyscale? IDR, and WON a decent seven figure award.

Anyway, so many (white) rabbits to follow.

If you’re willing to do the full process of submitting a transaction via the app, selecting an ATM and then going to y at ATM to the submit cash to help us test end to end, please let me know. We will be paying you back the full amount (plus maybe some incentive if i can get it cleared by Kyle). Specifically, I’m wanting to test a transaction at denominations from $10 to $50. Please either respond here or DM me if you’re willing / able to help out! Thanks guys!

title: atlbitlab
text:
In the future, we'll update you so you can surf the internet on you're own. In the meantime, I have scraped the text from the website @nonni_io is looking for feedback on:
  
Bitcoin Hackerspace Network | BTCHackNet
Welcome

View the Project on GitHub
ATLBitLab/bitcoin.hackerspace.network

Bitcoin Hackerspace Network | BitHackNet
BitcoinHackerspaceNetwork

Summary
Bitcoin Hackerspace Network (BitHackNet) is a self-sovereign movement to connect bitcoin-focused hackerspaces across the globe to form a decentralized network of bitcoin-focused, physical spaces. The specific goals of these hackerspaces vary, but the first principle that all are built upon is the idea of “building builders.” We believe that bitcoiners from near and far should be able to enjoy the feeling of their local bitcoin community while on the road. BitHackNet strives to achieve this goal by providing its member hackerspacers with the technology to easily onboard members in a cryptographically verifiable way. Digitally verifiable credentials provide the bitcoin hackerspace network with the ability to move freely between hackerspaces in different countries and cities within BitHackNet. A bitcoiner wanting to become a member of BitHackNet would contact a hackerspace participating in the network (typically one that is closest to them) and ask about onboarding. Generally speaking, “onboarding” requires selecting a memebership, paying an invoice and acquiring a BitHackNet credential from an issuer. Users with a BitHackNet credential enjoy various memeber benefits at any of the participating hackerspaces. Additionally, hackerspace organizers can rest assured that the out-of-towner standing in front of them has been onboarded by a network hackerspace they trust. In this way, we can provide easier access to hackerspaces for bitcoiners, provide more members and more revenue for hackerspaces, and provide the industry and world with more builders.

Goals
Publish open-source documentation to allow future hackerspaces the ability to onboard themselves (self-sovereign) into the network
Define clear business requirements with resepect to cross-hackerspace, intra-network memebership benefits
Define business model
Define cost structure and rev share / split
Define benefits to members from one hackerspace to another
Define clear technical requirements (functional and non-functional) from the business requirements
Implement definitions from biz/tech reqs
Define JSON schema representing a hackerspace’s belonging to / membership to the network
Define JSON schema for members + memberships
Define protocol for storing and retrieving JSON schema
Define protocol for proof request/response (request proof of membership/response with proof)
Implement TBD primitives building a “one-click” hackerspace technical repo
Research alternative protocols and interoperability with SSI/DIDs (e.g. nostr)
Onboard all bitcoin hackerspaces globally that want to participate
Hackerspace Credential Schema Suggestion (HACS)
Below are proposed credential schemas for the Bitcoin Hackerspace Network. If you have improvements or suggestions, please feel free to fork and submit a PR.

Version Credentials & Schemas Title Description
1 temp Temp Schema Defined large, nested schema as a catch all to get something completed for iterative sake
2 base Base Schemas Broke out each entity into its own credential, plan to reference parent child relationships beteween schemas

title: bitmiami
text:
@Marumover Abbot is fixed 🙂 sorry for the issues. Glad you want to try it out. Lmk if you have issues or anything like that. I'm a DM away.

Some basic rules of engagement for Abbot:
1. To get an immediate response in a group chat, simply @ him like I did above or reply to one of its messages. If you reply to his message, you don't need to @ him.
2. Otherwise, Abbot is coded to chine in every so often to the conversation. At first, he may seem a little wonky because he's got limited context but as you chat with him, he'll get better.
3. You can also DM him. He's coded to chat freely in DMs.

title: bitmiami
text:
I would have to read more on it but based on what the bot, It would be cool to have a regulatory framework for Bitcoin.

And $600 is about the limit for paying contractors without having to issue them a 1099 or whatever.

I'm okay with that because it treats it just like any other transaction.

I don't like the part where it talks about limiting self-custody of Bitcoin though.

That's madness.

If I'm crazy enough to bury all my money in my backyard then I damn well better be able to do it.

This is America still right?

But ultimately unless the bill takes away the taxes for buying things with Bitcoin then I think it's short-sided

title: bitmiami
text:
I can confirm 1 of the restaurants using us had $2000 CAD volume in about 2 months.
Another restaurant that just came on board about 3 weeks ago, has had $1000 CAD volume.
 
The businesses using us have some people paying with using their VISA. 
1 of the selling points I use when I'm trying to onboard merchants is that they will get increased overall sales because people come to support the business regardless of weather they pay in Bitcoin/Lightning or not.  Of course the majority of their increased volume of their new clientele is from Lightning.
This is all during a bear market. Imagine if it was a bull market.

I can also confirm that the majority of the business owners that are using us (Coinos.io) are HODLING their BTC and funding their cash registers with cash to balance at the end of night(s).

All this being said, are great tools to onboarding new users in to Bitcoin. When people are aware you can spend it at places, it improves no-coiners' confidence.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
Hey! Stephen and I would like to introduce Abbot (aka the ATL BitLab Bot). Many of you already encountered him either at the BitLab party or when he broke out of the Lab the other night to hang out with you in this channel.

Abbot was created to be a community helper bot. He can answer basic questions about bitcoin, help people find the meetup locations, and tell jokes. In the future, we plan for him to do even more!

To speak, the Abbot code copies messages from this channel to our server and then pipes them into OpenAI. In other words, when Abbot is activated, he stores data from this channel outside of telegram.

In our view, this isn’t a big deal because this telegram channel is public and unencrypted. Abbot is just taking data that’s already public and copying it elsewhere so we can make it more useful. Furthermore, we can have Abbot selectively exclude messages from people who want to opt-out.

However, not everybody may share this opinion. Therefore, we wanted to have a public discussion about this. How do you feel about Abbot being in this channel?

BitMiami is already using them in their channel. We would love to share this tool with our community, but we want to check community consensus on the matter first.

Should Abbot be in this channel? 👍 or 👎? You can DM Stephen or myself if you prefer to provide private feedback.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Ya that’s possible. It’s also possible to ignore messages from a username.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: The trade off of course is the fact that every piece of missing data make abbot less accurate and relevant to the overall chat context.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Right now, storing the messages is the hacky solution. I’m working as fast as I can on building an embedding database that’s turns the messages into decimals that GPT can understand. So instead of text being stored, it’s all just a bunch of numbers. And the next step after that would be to potentially implement a symmetric encryption on the data going into and coming out of that embeddings database

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Right now, storing the text of the messages is the hacky solution. I’m working as fast as I can on building an embedding database that’s turns the messages into decimals that GPT can understand. So instead of text being stored, it’s all just a bunch of numbers. title: Atlanta BitDevs Discussion
text:
HI everyone!  My name is Liz and I help run the Charlotte meetup group. Just wanted to s extend an invite to our event HODLween! There are 3 main events: a beef initiative dinner + pumpkin carving, HODLween market, and costume party. There will be music at all three events. Some highlights this year are that the majority of people involved are bitcoiners - bitcoin themed music and musicians, tarot card reader, live artist that was featured at Bitcoin Miami. 

The party will be a $1000 costume contest (paid in btc), karaoke, open bar, music! We'd love to see you there!   

Use code "10YEAR" for a $50 discount off the FULL HODL Pass.  If you have any questions or comments, please contact me.  

All details can be found at https://hodlween.party


There are also skeleton "satellite" events happening during the week - one including a bitcoin vs fiat debate with Guy Swann and Mark Yusko. You can also find this info on the website. 

Hope we see some of you there! 🎃⚡️

text: @atl_bitlab_bot what do you think?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: @atl_bitlab_bot what do you think of this wallet called safe pal?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Sus = suspicious ?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: That is what some people are using in Cuba 😔

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: And they are also buying their hardware wallet

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: What did you find that made you feel sus?

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: The biggest red flag

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Oh, don't mind me, I'm just being crabby. But to expand a little bit, I personally tend to be suspicious of any hardware wallet that's not Trezor or Coinkite. The only reason being, if the company doesn't have a reputation I recognize, I just worry if the hardware has been throughly vetted. Also, I see they minted some kind of "SPF token", so it makes me think there priorities are not only in making hardware but selling some kind of token. But having said that, I don't have a specific point to criticize them on. If folks are able to succesfully use this service to get bitcoin, then awesome.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: I appreciated. I am always suspicious, too much sometimes,that is why I wanted to check with you all. The fact they are using it there is a red flag itself. They don't have much access sometimes to the best things.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: I will check on some others they are using in other LATAN countries and see if they can use it.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: have you used this wallet ?  https://www.safepal.com/en/

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Low res images are a 🚩 for me.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: My barber is Cuban and he send money back every week. He said very few places take bitcoin. So if you send it there , you have to do a p2p back alley trade to get pesos

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: He said if you send dollars to the bank they will take the dollars but only allow your receiver to withdraw pesos.

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text: Yes all that very accurate

title: atlantabitdevsdiscussion
text:
one positive thing is they claim their app and HW wallet are open source
https://github.com/SafePalWallet/safepal-app
https://github.com/SafePalWallet/safepal-x1

however, having built mobile apps using flutter/dart, the app repo looks very sparse.
idk shit about hw wallet code, but it seems like that repo is also very sparse.
